title: 103_hr4111
content: The Act may be cited as the "Amtrak Investment Act of 1994". The Congress recognizes the importance of intercity rail passenger service as part of the national transportation system. Amtrak needs additional capital investment for modern equipment and facilities to provide high-quality service. Federal investment will help Amtrak offer world-class service and reduce operating costs in the long term. Amtrak's management should be accountable for Federal capital investment to improve service quality and financial health. The Secretary of Transportation should evaluate costs and revenue to ensure excellent service and wise use of funds. States can provide cost-efficient rail transportation and address local needs. Freight railroads are a critical part of the transportation system. The freight railroads are a critical part of the Nation's transportation infrastructure, ensuring efficient and cost-effective delivery of passenger trains. SEC. 3. WORLD CLASS SERVICE. Amends Section 24101(c) of title 49, United States Code to manage capital investment to provide customers with world class service. Section 24315(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code is amended to include projections of anticipated benefits and a report on benefits realized from funded projects since fiscal year 1994, focusing on improvements in Amtrak's service quality, productivity gains from facility and equipment upgrades, and environmental benefits. The curr_chunk discusses various benefits of funded projects, including operating cost reductions, environmental benefits, improvements to local transportation, enhanced mobility for disadvantaged individuals, improved revenue-to-cost ratio, reduced dependence on federal support, and decreased need for alternative transportation investments. The benefits should also be expressed as return on invested capital. State requested rail passenger transportation is discussed in Section 5. The amendment to Section 24704 of title 49, United States Code, includes changes to percentages and requirements for states, agencies, or persons providing rail passenger transportation services. Amtrak is authorized to contribute a certain percentage of operating losses and capital costs for rail passenger services. These changes apply from fiscal year 1996 onwards. The Secretary of Transportation will review the State-assisted rail passenger program within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Transportation will conduct a comprehensive review of Amtrak's State-assisted rail passenger services under section 24704 of title 49, United States Code. The report to Congress will include findings, conclusions, and recommendations for potential revisions to the program. It will also address the integration of these services into the basic system of intercity rail passenger transportation and explore new avenues for rail passenger transportation initiatives. SEC. 6. NORTHEAST CORRIDOR IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM. Amtrak is required to make capital improvements for the Northeast Corridor improvement program to operate reliable, high-speed rail passenger service, enhance capacity for intercity and commuter transportation, acquire train equipment, mitigate environmental impacts, and improve rail stations. Amtrak is mandated to make capital improvements for the Northeast Corridor improvement program, including designing and constructing an electrification system between Boston, Massachusetts, and New Haven, Connecticut, to accommodate a third mainline track for double-stack freight service to and from the Port of Davisville. The project aims to minimize the width of the right-of-way required for the third track by using portal structures and realigning existing tracks on bridges. Amtrak is required to transmit a report to Congress within 6 months detailing its electrification design between Davisville and Central Falls, Rhode Island, and efforts to comply with relevant regulations. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 24104 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to allocate specific amounts for fiscal years 1995 and 1996 to the Secretary for operating expenses of Amtrak. Amendments are made to allocate specific amounts for fiscal years 1995 and 1996 to the Secretary for operating expenses of Amtrak. This includes $17,000,000 for fiscal year 1995 and $17,000,000 for fiscal year 1996. Additionally, funds appropriated shall be provided to Amtrak upon request. SEC. 8. CAPITAL AND EQUIPMENT ACQUISITION ACCOUNT. Amends Chapter 243 of title 49, United States Code by adding a new section titled "SEC. 24316. CAPITAL AND EQUIPMENT ACQUISITION ACCOUNT." Amtrak is required to establish a Capital and Equipment Acquisition Account for acquiring passenger equipment, encouraging state and local investments in rail transportation facilities, and addressing critical capital priorities. The account can receive payments for equipment use, recovered claims, and other authorized amounts. The Secretary of Transportation will compare Amtrak's on-time performance with other modes of passenger transportation and report to Congress within a year. The report will explain differences in on-time performance, considering equipment age and condition. Additionally, there is a provision for cooperation with a study. Amtrak will cooperate with the Virginia State Department of Transportation on a study to reestablish rail service between Washington, D.C., and Bristol, Virginia. Additionally, there are provisions for station facilities in Burbank-Glendale-Pasadena, California. Amtrak will develop a plan for new station facilities at Burbank-Glendale-Pasadena Airport to accommodate intercity and commuter rail services. The plan will consider funding sources, space allocation, and costs without federal funds. Amtrak will submit a report to relevant committees in Congress. Amtrak will submit a report to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate by April 1, 1995, containing a plan for new station facilities at Burbank-Glendale-Pasadena Airport. SEC. 12. City of Ontario, California, station facilities. Amtrak will develop a plan for new or redeveloped station facilities in Ontario, California to meet the needs of intercity and commuter rail services. The plan will consider using a facility at Ontario International Airport, evaluate funding sources, and allocate space and costs among transportation services. The project will be completed with state, local, and private funding, without federal funds for Amtrak. Amtrak will report to the House of Representatives and the Committee on Commerce, Science. Amtrak will develop a plan for new or redeveloped station facilities in Ontario, California by April 1, 1995, to meet the needs of intercity and commuter rail services. The plan will be reported to the House of Representatives and the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation. SEC. 13. LAND CONVEYANCE. The conveyance of certain real property in Tulare County, California, granted to the Southern Pacific Railroad under the Act of 1866, is legalized and confirmed in the Redevelopment Agency of the city of Tulare. The conveyance was made by a Judgment in Condemnation and Final Order of Condemnation of the Superior Court. The Superior Court in Tulare County, California, issued a condemnation judgment in Action No. 150298, titled "Redevelopment Agency of the City of Tulare v. Southern Pacific Transportation Company" on March 10, 1992. The Southern Pacific Transportation Company conveyed a parcel of real property in Tulare, California, described by specific coordinates. The condemnation judgment in Tulare County, California, titled "Redevelopment Agency of the City of Tulare v. Southern Pacific Transportation Company" was issued on March 10, 1992. The Southern Pacific Transportation Company conveyed a parcel of real property in Tulare, California, with specific coordinates detailing the boundary lines along streets like "J" Street and Tulare Avenue. The condemnation judgment in Tulare County, California, titled "Redevelopment Agency of the City of Tulare v. Southern Pacific Transportation Company" was issued on March 10, 1992. The Southern Pacific Transportation Company conveyed a 0.69-acre parcel of real property in Tulare, California, with boundary lines along streets like "J" Street and Tulare Avenue. The parcel's coordinates include moving north parallel to "J" Street and then east to the Point of Beginning. SEC. 14. RESIDENCE OF EMPLOYEES. The amendments from the Amtrak Reauthorization and Improvement Act of 1990 apply to all periods before and after enactment.
